text: THE song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth—<po2>For thy love is better than wine.
Thine ointments have a goodly fragrance;<po2>Thy name is as ointment poured forth;<po3>Therefore do the maidens love thee.

Draw me, we will run after thee;<po2>The king hath brought me into his chambers;<po3>We will be glad and rejoice in thee,<po4>We will find thy love more fragrant than wine!<po5>Sincerely do they love thee.
‘I am black, but comely,<po2>O ye daughters of Jerusalem,<po3>As the tents of Kedar,<po4>As the curtains of Solomon.

Look not upon me, that I am swarthy,<po2>That the sun hath tanned me;<po3>My mother’s sons were incensed against me,<po4>They made me keeper of the vineyards;<po5>But mine own vineyard have I not kept.’
Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth,<po2>Where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon;<po3>For why should I be as one that veileth herself<po4>Beside the flocks of thy companions?
If thou know not, O thou fairest among women,<po2>Go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock<po3>And feed thy kids, beside the shepherds’ tents.
I have compared thee, O my love,<po2>To a steed in Pharaoh’s chariots.
Thy cheeks are comely with circlets,<po2>Thy neck with beads.
We will make thee circlets of gold<po2>With studs of silver.
While the king sat at his table,<po2>My spikenard sent forth its fragrance.
My beloved is unto me as a bag of myrrh,<po2>That lieth betwixt my breasts.
My beloved is unto me as a cluster of henna<po2>In the vineyards of En-gedi.
Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair;<po2>Thine eyes are as doves.
Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant;<po2>Also our couch is leafy.
The beams of our houses are cedars,<po2>And our panels are cypresses.
I am a rose of Sharon,<po2>A lily of the valleys.
As a lily among thorns,<po2>So is my love among the daughters.
As an apple-tree among the trees of the wood,<po2>So is my beloved among the sons.<po3>Under its shadow I delighted to sit,<po4>And its fruit was sweet to my taste.
He hath brought me to the banqueting-house,<po2>And his banner over me is love.
‘Stay ye me with dainties, refresh me with apples;<po2>For I am love-sick.’
Let his left hand be under my head,<po2>And his right hand embrace me.
‘I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,<po2>By the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field,<po3>That ye awaken not, nor stir up love, until it please.’
Hark! my beloved! behold, he cometh,<po2>Leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
My beloved is like a gazelle or a young hart;<po2>Behold, he standeth behind our wall,<po3>He looketh in through the windows,<po4>He peereth through the lattice.
My beloved spoke, and said unto me:<po2>‘Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
For, lo, the winter is past,<po2>The rain is over and gone;
The flowers appear on the earth;<po2>The time of singing is come,<po3>And the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
The fig-tree putteth forth her green figs,<po2>And the vines in blossom give forth their fragrance.<po3>Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the covert of the cliff,<po2>Let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice;<po3>For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.’
‘Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vineyards;<po2>For our vineyards are in blossom.’
My beloved is mine, and I am his,<po2>That feedeth among the lilies.
Until the day breathe, and the shadows flee away,<po2>Turn, my beloved, and be thou like a gazelle or a young hart<po3>Upon the mountains of spices.
By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth;<po2>I sought him, but I found him not.
‘I will rise now, and go about the city, In the streets and in the broad ways,<po2>I will seek him whom my soul loveth.’<po3>I sought him, but I found him not.
The watchmen that go about the city found me:<po2>‘Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?’

Scarce had I passed from them,<po2>When I found him whom my soul loveth:<po3>I held him, and would not let him go,<po4>Until I had brought him into my mother’s house,<po5>And into the chamber of her that conceived me.
‘I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,<po2>By the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field,<po3>That ye awaken not, nor stir up love,<po4>Until it please.’
Who is this that cometh up out of the wilderness<po2>Like pillars of smoke,<po3>Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,<po4>With all powders of the merchant?
Behold, it is the litter of Solomon;<po2>Threescore mighty men are about it,<po3>Of the mighty men of Israel.
They all handle the sword,<po2>And are expert in war;<po3>Every man hath his sword upon his thigh,<po4>Because of dread in the night.
King Solomon made himself a palanquin<po2>Of the wood of Lebanon.
He made the pillars thereof of silver,<po2>The top thereof of gold,<po3>The seat of it of purple,<po4>The inside thereof being inlaid with love,<po5>From the daughters of Jerusalem.

Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion,<po2>And gaze upon king Solomon,<po3>Even upon the crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him in the day of his espousals,<po4>And in the day of the gladness of his heart.
Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair;<po2>Thine eyes are as doves behind thy veil;<po3>Thy hair is as a flock of goats, that trail down from mount Gilead.
Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes all shaped alike,<po2>Which are come up from the washing;<po3>Whereof all are paired, and none faileth among them.
Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet,<po2>And thy mouth is comely;<po3>Thy temples are like a pomegranate split open<po4>Behind thy veil.
Thy neck is like the tower of David<po2>Builded with turrets,<po3>Whereon there hang a thousand shields, All the armour of the mighty men.
Thy two breasts are like two fawns<po2>That are twins of a gazelle,<po3>Which feed among the lilies.
Until the day breathe,<po2>And the shadows flee away,<po3>I will get me to the mountain of myrrh,<po4>And to the hill of frankincense.
Thou art all fair, my love;<po2>And there is no spot in thee.
Come with me from Lebanon, my bride,<po2>With me from Lebanon;<po3>Look from the top of Amana,<po4>From the top of Senir and Hermon,<po5>From the lions’ dens,<po6>From the mountains of the leopards.
Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my bride;<po2>Thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes,<po3>With one bead of thy necklace.
How fair is thy love, my sister, my bride!<po2>How much better is thy love than wine!<po3>And the smell of thine ointments than all manner of spices!
Thy lips, O my bride, drop honey—<po2>Honey and milk are under thy tongue;<po3>And the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.
A garden shut up is my sister, my bride;<po2>A spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
Thy shoots are a park of pomegranates,<po2>With precious fruits;<po3>Henna with spikenard plants,
Spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon,<po2>With all trees of frankincense;<po3>Myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices.
Thou art a fountain of gardens,<po2>A well of living waters,<po3>And flowing streams from Lebanon.
Awake, O north wind;<po2>And come, thou south;<po3>Blow upon my garden,<po4>That the spices thereof may flow out.<po5>Let my beloved come into his garden,<po6>And eat his precious fruits.

I am come into my garden, my sister, my bride;<po2>I have gathered my myrrh with my spice;<po3>I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey;<po4>I have drunk my wine with my milk.<po5>Eat, O friends;<po6>Drink, yea, drink abundantly, O beloved.
I sleep, but my heart waketh;<po2>Hark! my beloved knocketh:<po3>‘Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled;<po4>For my head is filled with dew, My locks with the drops of the night.’
I have put off my coat;<po2>How shall I put it on?<po3>I have washed my feet;<po4>How shall I defile them?
My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door,<po2>And my heart was moved for him.
I rose up to open to my beloved;<po2>And my hands dropped with myrrh,<po3>And my fingers with flowing myrrh,<po4>Upon the handles of the bar.
I opened to my beloved;<po2>But my beloved had turned away, and was gone.<po3>My soul failed me when he spoke.<po4>I sought him, but I could not find him;<po5>I called him, but he gave me no answer.
The watchmen that go about the city found me,<po2>They smote me, they wounded me;<po3>The keepers of the walls took away my mantle from me.
‘I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,<po2>If ye find my beloved, what will ye tell him?<po3>That I am love-sick.’
‘What is thy beloved more than another beloved,<po2>O thou fairest among women?<po3>What is thy beloved more than another beloved,<po4>That thou dost so adjure us?’
‘My beloved is white and ruddy,<po2>Pre-eminent above ten thousand.
His head is as the most fine gold,<po2>His locks are curled,<po3>And black as a raven.
His eyes are like doves<po2>Beside the water-brooks;<po3>Washed with milk,<po4>And fitly set.
His cheeks are as a bed of spices,<po2>As banks of sweet herbs;<po3>His lips are as lilies,<po4>Dropping with flowing myrrh.
His hands are as rods of gold<po2>Set with beryl;<po3>His body is as polished ivory<po4>Overlaid with sapphires.
His legs are as pillars of marble,<po2>Set upon sockets of fine gold;<po3>His aspect is like Lebanon,<po4>Excellent as the cedars.
His mouth is most sweet;<po2>Yea, he is altogether lovely.<po3>This is my beloved, and this is my friend,<po4>O daughters of Jerusalem.’
‘Whither is thy beloved gone,<po2>O thou fairest among women?<po3>Whither hath thy beloved turned him,<po4>That we may seek him with thee?’
‘My beloved is gone down into his garden,<po2>To the beds of spices,<po3>To feed in the gardens,<po4>And to gather lilies.
I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine,<po2>That feedeth among the lilies.’
Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah,<po2>Comely as Jerusalem,<po3>Terrible as an army with banners.
Turn away thine eyes from me,<po2>For they have overcome me.<po3>Thy hair is as a flock of goats,<po4>That trail down from Gilead.
Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes,<po2>Which are come up from the washing;<po3>Whereof all are paired,<po4>And none faileth among them.
Thy temples are like a pomegranate split open<po2>Behind thy veil.
There are threescore queens,<po2>And fourscore concubines,<po3>And maidens without number.

My dove, my undefiled, is but one;<po2>She is the only one of her mother;<po3>She is the choice one of her that bore her.<po4>The daughters saw her, and called her happy;<po5>Yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.
Who is she that looketh forth as the dawn,<po2>Fair as the moon,<po3>Clear as the sun,<po4>Terrible as an army with banners?
I went down into the garden of nuts,<po2>To look at the green plants of the valley,<po3>To see whether the vine budded,<po4>And the pomegranates were in flower.
Before I was aware, my soul set me<po2>Upon the chariots of my princely people.

Return, return, O Shulammite;Return, return, that we may look upon thee.

What will ye see in the Shulammite?As it were a dance of two companies.
How beautiful are thy steps in sandals,<po2>O prince’s daughter!<po3>The roundings of thy thighs are like the links of a chain,<po4>The work of the hands of a skilled workman.
Thy navel is like a round goblet,<po2>Wherein no mingled wine is wanting;<po3>Thy belly is like a heap of wheat<po4>Set about with lilies.
Thy two breasts are like two fawns<po2>That are twins of a gazelle.
Thy neck is as a tower of ivory;<po2>Thine eyes as the pools in Heshbon,<po3>By the gate of Bath-rabbim;<po4>Thy nose is like the tower of Lebanon<po5>Which looketh toward Damascus.
Thy head upon thee is like Carmel,<po2>And the hair of thy head like purple;<po3>The king is held captive in the tresses thereof.
How fair and how pleasant art thou,<po2>O love, for delights!
This thy stature is like to a palm-tree,<po2>And thy breasts to clusters of grapes.
I said: ‘I will climb up into the palm-tree,<po2>I will take hold of the branches thereof;<po3>And let thy breasts be as clusters of the vine,<po4>And the smell of thy countenance like apples;
And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine,<po2>That glideth down smoothly for my beloved,<po3>Moving gently the lips of those that are asleep.’
I am my beloved’s,<po2>And his desire is toward me.
Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field;<po2>Let us lodge in the villages.
Let us get up early to the vineyards;<po2>Let us see whether the vine hath budded,<po3>Whether the vine-blossom be opened,<po4>And the pomegranates be in flower;<po5>There will I give thee my love.
The mandrakes give forth fragrance,<po2>And at our doors are all manner of precious fruits,<po3>New and old,<po4>Which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
Oh that thou wert as my brother,<po2>That sucked the breasts of my mother!<po3>When I should find thee without, I would kiss thee;<po4>Yea, and none would despise me.
I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother’s house,<po2>That thou mightest instruct me;<po3>I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine,<po4>Of the juice of my pomegranate.
His left hand should be under my head,<po2>And his right hand should embrace me.
‘I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem:<po2>Why should ye awaken, or stir up love,<po3>Until it please?’

Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness,<po2>Leaning upon her beloved?<po3>Under the apple-tree I awakened thee;<po4>There thy mother was in travail with thee;<po5>There was she in travail and brought thee forth.
Set me as a seal upon thy heart,As a seal upon thine arm;For love is strong as death,Jealousy is cruel as the grave;The flashes thereof are flashes of fire, A very flame of the Lord.
Many waters cannot quench love,<po2>Neither can the floods drown it;<po3>If a man would give all the substance of his house for love,<po4>He would utterly be contemned.
We have a little sister,<po2>And she hath no breasts;<po3>What shall we do for our sister<po4>In the day when she shall be spoken for?
If she be a wall,<po2>We will build upon her a turret of silver;<po3>And if she be a door,<po4>We will enclose her with boards of cedar.
I am a wall,<po2>And my breasts like the towers thereof;<po3>Then was I in his eyes<po4>As one that found peace.
Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon;<po2>He gave over the vineyard unto keepers;<po3>Every one for the fruit thereof<po4>Brought in a thousand pieces of silver.
My vineyard, which is mine, is before me;<po2>Thou, O Solomon, shalt have the thousand,<po3>And those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.
Thou that dwellest in the gardens,<po2>The companions hearken for thy voice:<po3>‘Cause me to hear it.’
Make haste, my beloved,<po2>And be thou like to a gazelle or to a young hart<po3>Upon the mountains of spices.
